content.description: Trichotillomania is characterized by recurrent pulling out of one's hair, resulting in hair loss, with repeated attempts to decrease or stop the behavior. The hair pulling causes clinically significant distress or impairment and is not better explained by another medical or psychiatric condition.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Recurrent pulling out of hair, resulting in hair loss. B. Repeated attempts to decrease or stop hair pulling. C. The hair pulling causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning. D. The hair pulling or hair loss is not attributable to another medical condition (e.g., dermatological disease). E. The hair pulling is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder (e.g., attempts to improve a perceived defect in body dysmorphic disorder).
content.prevalence: Estimated 1â€“2% of the population; more common in females.
content.age_of_onset: Typically begins in early adolescence, though childhood onset is possible.
content.prognosis: Variable course; some have chronic symptoms, others experience episodic remission. Early treatment and behavioral strategies improve outcomes.

circuitry: Involvement of cortico-striatal-thalamo-cortical circuits implicated in habit formation.
neurochemistry: Potential serotonin, dopamine, and glutamate dysregulation.
neurobiology.genetic_environmental: Familial aggregation; environmental triggers include stress and boredom.

history_psychosocial: Onset, frequency, duration, and triggers of hair pulling.
Hair pulling sites, attempts to stop, and impact on self-esteem.
Co-occurring skin picking, nail biting, or other repetitive behaviors.
medical_assessment: Dermatologic examination to rule out other causes of hair loss.
Screen for trichophagia (hair ingestion) and related GI complications.
risk_stratification: Assess for functional impairment, shame, or social withdrawal.
Identify comorbid psychiatric conditions such as anxiety or depression.
evaluation.team_and_process: Psychiatry, dermatology, and behavioral therapy collaboration.

behavioral: Recurrent pulling of scalp, eyebrow, eyelash, or other body hair.
Rituals around pulling (e.g., inspecting, rolling, chewing hair).
emotional: Tension before pulling or when resisting the urge.

severity_levels.mild: Pulling occurs occasionally with minimal hair loss and low distress.
severity_levels.moderate: Pulling occurs regularly, noticeable hair loss, moderate distress.
severity_levels.severe: Pulling is frequent, causes significant bald patches, high distress, and functional impairment.

impact_on_life.school_work: Absenteeism or reduced performance due to embarrassment or avoidance.
impact_on_life.social: Social withdrawal, wearing hats or wigs to conceal hair loss.
impact_on_life.medical: Dermatologic complications, possible trichobezoar if hair ingestion occurs.

psychotherapy: Habit Reversal Training (HRT) as first-line treatment.
Stimulus control strategies to reduce triggers.
Acceptance and Commitment Therapy (ACT) and Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) modules for emotional regulation.
medications: SSRIs for comorbid anxiety or depression (variable efficacy for hair pulling itself).
N-acetylcysteine (NAC) for reduction of urges in some patients.
neuromodulation: Investigational use of rTMS in treatment-resistant cases.
lifestyle_interventions: Mindfulness practices to increase awareness of pulling urges.
Keeping hair covered or hands occupied.

treatment_goals: Reduce hair pulling frequency and severity.
Promote hair regrowth and prevent medical complications.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing hair loss solely to dermatologic causes.
Failure to ask about pulling behaviors due to stigma.
overdiagnosis_factors: Normal grooming behaviors mistaken for pathological pulling.
Hair loss from other causes labeled as trichotillomania without behavioral confirmation.
warning_signs: Development of GI symptoms suggestive of trichobezoar
self_help_strategies: Keep a hair pulling diary to identify triggers.
Use fidget tools or stress balls to occupy hands.
Wear hairstyles that reduce access to pulling sites.

childhood: Often less awareness of pulling; family-based interventions helpful.
adolescence: Greater embarrassment, social impact; peer support can help.
adulthood: Chronic patterns may be more resistant; combined behavioral and pharmacologic approaches.

real_life_examples: A 14-year-old begins pulling out eyelashes during exam stress, successfully treated with habit reversal training and mindfulness.
A 35-year-old with longstanding scalp hair pulling improves after NAC supplementation and therapy.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek help if hair pulling leads to visible hair loss, emotional distress, or interference with daily life.
